n Wed, Jan 6, 2010 at 10:08 AM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:

>>
>>
=
>> Rocco,
>>
>> Note that these kinds of dependencies could be dynamically =
inferred
>> over time. With a complete history of pass/fail patterns, a cor=
e
>> runner could notice that test B never passes when test A fails, and
>>=
 that test A is failing today, and thus, mark B as "Skipped (98%
>> confide=
nce of no new information after testA failed)"
>>
>> This seems like a real=
 win over manual dependency annotation, and I'd
>> be delighted to take a l=
ook at it if there were enough users (usual
>> rules--create a github issue=
, and vote, vote, vote)
>>
> This doesn't seem very optimal since the knowl=
edge can only be gained when
> tests fail, which won't be the case most of =
the time.

> Again, why leave this up to what seems like a difficult and un=
predictable
> heuristic when it's so easy for users to explicitly state the=
ir dependencies
> in annotations?

What I'm hearing is that in your experie=
nce, most projects have test
failures that are rare.  I'm also hearing that=
 your instinct is that
human annotation of dependencies is a win.

I'm surp=
rised.  I expected to hear either "adding and maintaining
dependency annota=
tions is worth my time because I'd otherwise lose so
much of my time to dia=
gnosing confusing frequent failures", or
"Frankly, my tests don't fail enou=
gh of the time for any kind of
dependency solution to make much impact".  C=
an you explain further?

As a separate issue, I also hear that you're guess=
ing my stated
heuristic would be hard to write and unpredictable.  My insti=
ncts are
the opposite in both cases, so we'd probably have to prototype and=
 get
some data to answer the question.
